<robotex> You must add a small piece to set up the app icon in the Software Center. (It's a bit ugly, but there's no other way to do it at the moment.) Define an override_dh_gencontrol target that copies your image icon outside the top-level directory (to "../myapp.png"), and then adds the icon to the package meta-data. The name of the file added to the package meta-data must exactly match the XB-Icon filename in the debian/control file. It has to be a
<robotex> PNG icon, and not SVG or some other format.

<robotex>         dh_gencontrol
<robotex>         cp icons/myapp-64x64.png ../myapp.png
<robotex>         dpkg-distaddfile myapp.png raw-meta-data -

<mcphail> zubozrout: this is essential reading: https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/blog/2015/04/13/inner-workings-sdk/
<mcphail> zubozrout: getting a chroot set up takes time, but it is very automated and foolproof
<zubozrout> mcphail: ok, thanks :)
<mcphail> zubozrout: the next thing you have to do is get a version of SDL which works with Mir. See: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mcphail/ubuntu-touch-sdl-template/master/lib/src/how_to_build_sdl_for_ubuntu_phone.txt
<mcphail> zubozrout: you can take the SDL libs from that github repo. They "wrok"
<mcphail> *work

<mcphail> zubozrout: not quite, but when you have the framework set up is is simple
<mcphail> zubozrout: the difficulty is getting the first steps done
<mcphail> zubozrout: you can then compile or download the ARM binary for your SDL app and roll it in a .click package
<zubozrout> mcphail: well, the app has to be compiled with the above SDL libs, yes.
<mcphail> zubozrout: you can compile _against_ any SDL2 libs, but you have to roll that specific version into your .click
<mcphail> zubozrout: that means you can take any precompiled binary from the Ubuntu repos, but roll it with my SDL2

<lifeless> yah
<lifeless> in Ubuntu, any motu can upload any package in universe; there is no concept of NMU
<lifeless> and any core-dev can upload any package in main or universe
<lifeless> that said, people do specialise, and uploading e.g. a kernel when you have no idea about the kernels would be frowned upon, but the maintainer lock is well and truely gone.
<lifeless> its one of the major social differences between ubuntu and debian package management
<lifeless> teams are social grouping for people working on the same thing; we'd need to either a) only allow devs (core-dev + motu) into such teams, or b) ignore such teams for the purpose of access control, to do acl's sanely
<lifeless> we've chosen b) because that allows interested folk that are only prospective developers (aka going through NM) to participate more
<lifeless> from ubuntu's perspective you are currently a prospective developer, you haven't passed the assessment to get upload rights & all that comes with that.

<lifeless> luks: so here are the parameters: We want adjacent texts to combine into the same pack as we combine packs, so that they can be efficiently delta compressed. We want to provide a natural cap on latency. We always have to replace an entire pack - we can't delete from a pack, nor add to one. We never want a user to have to worry about the internals.
<lifeless> luks: over http we: perform bisection in 64K chunks on the .*ix indices. Then we plan a readv for each pack, and readv the data we want precisely out of the pack file.
<lifeless> luks: we do one readv per pack for the revisions we need. Then one readv per pack for the inventories we need. Another for the text deltas. And finally one for digital signatures.
<lifeless> luks: each readv is done in ascending order to make range combining as efficient as possible.

<lifeless> jam-laptop: to setup a repo where a fetch will find a missing text parent, here is an easy way
<lifeless> jam-laptop: repo a: do two commits, A and B that add and alter a file foo, with id foo-id
<lifeless> repo b: do one commit, A, that does not add the file foo
<lifeless> then fetching into b from a will only copy the deltas for B, and the text parent for foo-id will be absent.
<lifeless> long term this test has some flaws, but it will ensure that the sanity checking we need today is in place; and defers the other work until we have code that will need it, which is a good thing.

<fullermd> It would do us well to explain once why hg's hardlinking is not a capable alternative to shared repos, instead of having to fumble it up every time it comes up.
<Peng> Hg's hardlinking also has its benefits, mainly that you can clone to anywhere on the filesystem, not just inside the shared repo.
<fullermd> Well as long as you're using a fs that supports hardlinks.  And cloning on one fs (though I don't know if shared repos can span fsen; branches can't)
<jam> Peng: though packs will also support hardlinking without having to ever break the links
<jam> fullermd: shared repos can span fs
<jam> you just have to have a containing fs
<jam> so if you put one it /
<jam> all your branches would share across all filesystems
<jam> we do expect that .bzr/* is on the same filesystem as all working files
<jam> so that we can do atomic "os.rename()"
<fullermd> (mind you, I have a very low opinion of any fs that _doesn't_ support hardlinks.  But they are out there.)
<jam> fullermd: and there are those like HPFS+ that *do* but very poorly
<jam> (as in, performance is better without hardlinking)
<fullermd> Mm.  Packs may support hardlinking without strictly speaking having to break, but they still have all the same side effects as breaking.
<jam> fullermd: the problem with knits is that you have to probe and see if you need to break
<jam> before writing to them
<jam> (same thing for revlog)
<jam> which means it isn't safe to do over sftp
<jam> etc
<jam> but it *is* safe to use packs in a similar fashion
<jam> over sftp when the remote one is hardlinkde
<jam> hardlinked
<fullermd> Safety isn't my argument against it.  It's that it's not shared; your branches only share storage as long as you don't touch either one.
<fullermd> Soon's you start commiting in one or the other, you progressively work back toward 2*space.
<jam> fullermd: completely true
<jam> and packs have the side effect that changing 1 file 10,000 times
<jam> will get you back to 2x space
<jam> because it breaks the link for "unrelated" files
<fullermd> So saying "We don't need shared repos, hardlinks do just as well" is false, even if it's done completely safely.
<jam> (though if one file is changing 10,000 times, you probably don't have that much in common anyway)
<jam> fullermd: I agree (I certainly never made that assertion, I like shared repos) but that doesn't mean it is incompatible with also doing hardlinks
<jam> probably our bigger impedance to hardlinking packs
<fullermd> Oh, I'm arguing against the statement I've heard from hg before (and is on their reponse page against our BzrVsHg)

<abentley> So I started hacking on per-file base selection yesterday, and I found a locality-of-reference problem.

<abentley> The file content is stored in the versionedfile.  The file type is stored in the inventory.
<abentley> So to do it absolutely correctly, I'd have to retrieve all the trees for the selected revisions.
<abentley> Because the selected revision may not be a file-- it may be a directory, symlink or tree reference.

<lifeless> now, if the kind is the same on both tips

<abentley> In fact, we're already assuming it's a file on both tips.  Otherwise, we wouldn't need a base at all.

<loxs> hello folks, does bazaar provide a way for customized user permissions, like this is possible with svn?
<AfC> loxs: Execute bit has been supported since the beginning.
<AfC> loxs: are you looking for more than that?
<spiv> loxs: you mean access control on the repository itself?
<AfC> spiv: (oh, right)
<loxs> yes. the central one... I want to be able to give various users permissions to only commit code to a particular directory/file
<spiv> loxs: the simplest solution is to use ordinary user accounts and filesystem permissions to restrict write access per branch. (or per project, if you use a shared repository per project, as is common.)
<spiv> loxs: depending on what you're looking for, you *might* be interested in using a tool like PQM (https://launchpad.net/pqm) as a gatekeeper that vets commits to a central branch, e.g. to make sure all commits pass "make check"
<spiv> loxs: I don't know of any out-of-the-box ways to restrict write access of just particular directories/files within a branch.  You could probably configure or extend PQM to do something like that, if PQM's workflow suits your use case.
<spiv> loxs: but it'd probably be simplest to make separate branches for those parts of your tree, and use regular filesystem permissions.
<spiv> If commits to the central branch are exclusively done over bzr+ssh, you could write a plugin for the server that installs a pre_change_branch_tip hook function to vet the commit.
<spiv> While a server-side pre_change_branch_tip hook should work well in theory, I don't think there's much infrastructure to make writing those sorts of hook functions convenient yet.  (it's not well documented how to write a hook function that gets a list of files that are touched by the proposed revision, for instance)

<lfaraone> hi, what's the difference between branch and checkout?
<luks> lfaraone: the commands or the terms in general?
<lfaraone> luks: both.
<luks> let's start with the terms first, then :)
<luks> a checkout is the area you work with, it's basically the working tree with some local metadata
<luks> every checkout is linked to a branch, and this branch can be either local or remote
<luks> so that if you commit the working tree, it will update the linked branch
<luks> and it's also possible to have 'bound branch', which is a branch that will update another remote branch on commit
<lfaraone> ah.
<luks> so, when you run 'bzr checkout --lightweight', it will create a local checkout bound to a remote branch
<lfaraone> Now a more practical question: I'm trying to do work on a svn branch, but it has 6959
<lfaraone> revisions, and this is over ssh. can I check out the most recent rev?
<luks> and 'bzr checkout' will create a local checkout, local branch and the branch is bound to another remote branch
<lfaraone> s/branch/repo/
<luks> with bzr-svn?
<lfaraone> luks: yeah.
<luks> then just 'bzr branch svn+ssh://host/path/to/svn/repo'
<luks> (or whatever is the scheme svn uses for ssh named)
<lfaraone> luks: I don't want to download the complete branch history, I only need the most recent rev.
<lfaraone> luks: it's going to take an age that way.
<luks> lfaraone: you can try 'bzr checkout --lightweight ...', but I doubt it will be any faster
<luks> lfaraone: or just use svn, if you don't intend to commit to it :)
<lfaraone> luks: heh...
<luks> bzr-svn needs to know the metadata about the whole history
<luks> so at minimum that needs to be downloaded
<luks> how do you want to use bzr with no history, though?

<Odd_Bloke> rotty: Are you talking about repositories or branches?
<rotty> Odd_Bloke: aren't those the same in bzr?
<Odd_Bloke> rotty: No.
<Odd_Bloke> A repository is Just a Bunch Of Revisions.  A branch is a pointer to one of those revisions (which in turn point to their parents and so on, giving you history).
<Odd_Bloke> rotty: Often, the repository and the branch will be in the same location, but not necessarily.
<Odd_Bloke> For example, when using shared repositories.

<MvG> I just realized that I can't seem to have a lightweight checkout tree of a heavyweight checkout without a tree. The advantage of bzr+ssh = speed/encryption and the advantage of bzr+http(s) = encryption/flexible user management, correct? I'm thinking about setting up bzr+http (ro) and bzr+https (rw) and connect apache to a small db (test) or ldap (production) instead of using bzr+ssh and just would like a small piece of advice _before_ I start setting it up.
<lifeless> SWAT: the smart server can work over http
<lifeless> SWAT: so you've presented a false dichotomy ;)
<maxb> lifeless: The problem with the feature as currently implemented is that it discards revisions solely based on ancestry. What it should/could do, to be correct, is discard revisions only if a merge results in there being no changes to commit.
<lifeless> maxb: perhaps
<lifeless> maxb: though I don't think I agree
<maxb> You don't think that it's wrong that rebase is lossy by default?
<lifeless> rebase is by definition lossy
<lifeless> its its raison d'etre
<maxb> Well... far more lossy than the basic concept of rebasing inherently includes
<lifeless> anyhow, a merge that includes something from the branch being rebased *on* should be discarded.
<lifeless> whether or not there are textual changes is perhaps a case for a warning.
<maxb> Yes.... but only if there aren't relevant textual changes remaining on merging it
<lifeless> maybe
<lifeless> I think it really depends on the exact change
<lifeless> and what it means semantically.
<SWAT> lifeless: ah, right, thanks. Let me put it differently: is it adviseable to use bzr+http(s) instead of bzr+ssh or is it all neglectable?
<lifeless> maxb: it probably needs to be put way down at the bottom of the rebase in fact, for the case of a merge already in the base.
<lifeless> maxb: OTOH a merge from a branch not merged to base, should be kept.
<lifeless> SWAT: shouldn't be any significant differences in performance.
<lifeless> SWAT: if there are, they are bugs
<SWAT> lifeless: thanks a lot. I'll leave you to your other discussion(s). Cheers
<maxb> I don't think it makes sense to try to replay merges out-of-order if that's what you're suggesting - the merge is on top of other changes on your branch being rebased, and is likely to have textual dependencies on them
<lifeless> maxb: I'm not sure I was totally clear about the case being discussed
<maxb> Well, I'm approaching this from the PoV of "It's never OK to discard a merge revision purely based on ancestry, you have to see if there are relevant textual changes" - because the act of resolving conflicts when the merge was done may include making valuable changes.
<maxb> By way of a specific example: we had a Launchpad branch for a newer python version. When a new script was added on trunk, the shebang had to be changed as part of merging the addition to the branch.
<maxb> A purely ancestry-based approach would silently lose that sort of change
<lifeless> maxb: but thats my example
<maxb> ?
<lifeless> maxb: if you have the rev merged earlier you need the shebang earlier too
<maxb> hmm. The idea of reordering changesets instead of just replaying the graph maintaining its shape is scary
<lifeless> maxb: rebasing anything where revisions merged higher up that are already in the new base is non trivial.
<lifeless> maxb: (consider the typical loom usecase)
<lifeless> maxb: where what you are rebasing is just a non-linear but still discrete subgraph, its easy.
<lifeless> this is one of the problems with merges and rebase.

 * mwhudson remembers that there was a bzr bug that resulted in repos being very fragmented across many packs
<mwhudson> (a) am i right (b) is it fixed (c) which version has the fix?
<lifeless> mwhudson: no, there was a bug where inside a pack we didn't consolidate properly.
<lifeless> mwhudson: any 2.0+ is fine.
<mwhudson> lifeless: ah ok
<mwhudson> http://bazaar.launchpad.net/~launchpad-pqm/launchpad/db-devel/.bzr/repository/packs/ has 26 packs, is that more than i should expect?
<lifeless> mwhudson: no
<lifeless> mwhudson: you could get at at 999 revisions, for instance.
<lifeless> mwhudson: dump-btree on the packs-name index will tell you if you have stale packs
<mwhudson> lifeless: seems we do
<lifeless> mwhudson: the number of packs you have is dependent on the exact operations that have taken place. The way it works is that there is an upper bound.
<lifeless> and when the bound is exceeded by a transaction, an incremental pack is triggered, which consolidates the smallest (by rev count) packs into one, stopping at the point that will be under the upper bound.
<lifeless> mwhudson: the upper bound is sum(int(digit) for digit in str(repo.revision_count()))
<mathiaz> Hi - Is there  a way to find the revno of the common ancestor for two branches?
<mwhudson> lifeless: right, that's what i thought
<lifeless> mwhudson: so 998 revisons == 26 as upper bound
<mwhudson> i guess i was too lazy to work out what that is for launchpad :)
<lifeless> and in general, upper bound ~= 10*log10(revcount)
<lifeless> mathiaz: not really, no. there is show-ancestor I think.
<mathiaz> lifeless: ok found a workaround for ubuntu package branches
<mathiaz> lifeless: bzr log -rancestor:../squeeze (in the lucid branch)
<mathiaz> lifeless: ^^ that gives the revno of the common ancestor
<_habnabit> Is it possible to only merge part of a revision, without merging the whole revision?
<Peng> I suppose you can shelve or revert some of the changes.
<Peng> History-wise, you can either record that the revision was merged or not (a cherrypick).
<_habnabit> So, merge that revision, shelve the changes, and commit?
<Peng> If you want to.
<Peng> What are you trying to do?
<spiv> _habnabit: yes, that works.  But if that records as a merge, it means future merges will not try to merge the bits you left out.
<_habnabit> I'm trying to backport changes from a fork of a particular project, but one revision has some changes I don't want to backport.
<spiv> Which may be what you want?
<spiv> Ok, my guess is that is what you want, then :)
<_habnabit> I'm not sure what the exact connotations of what you said are, so.
<spiv> Well, after you 'bzr merge' but before you 'bzr commit', look at 'bzr status'; it (usually) will show "pending merges"
<jam> igc: not critical at all, just genuine. I haven't had time because of X and Y and Z, and if someone else *has* the time, I'm really far behind
<jam> and it would be great
<jam> its a fair amount of work to announce
<jam> and I didn't open my laptop really until this evening for a little bit
<spiv> _habnabit: commit records the contents of the files, but it can also record "revision X was merged in at this point".  If it does, then the next time you 'bzr merge' in that branch bzr will know that the changes in that revision have already been merged and will not merge them again.
<_habnabit> spiv, ah.
<_habnabit> I did the merge, but it doesn't show that there are any pending merges.
<spiv> _habnabit: so the question is basically, "the next time you merge from that branch into this one, do you want bzr to try merge all these changes again, or assume they have been merged (so only newer changes should be considered)"
<_habnabit> There were conflicts, though.
<_habnabit> (And I resolved the conflicts.)
<spiv> Conflicts don't affect that; but if you do 'bzr merge -r X..Y' or 'bzr merge subdirectory/of/branch' or something like that, it won't record a pending merge in the working tree.
<_habnabit> Ahh, I see.
<_habnabit> Yeah, I did merge -r.
<spiv> Because the merge record is just "this revision ID is another parent of this revision"
<spiv> Which can't track revision ranges or merging just some files, etc.
<spiv> We'd like to track these more complicated cases, but we haven't implemented that yet.

<mwhudson> LaserJock: no, obsolete-packs is probably still there
<LaserJock> ok, well I just rm'd the contents of obsolete-packs
<Peng> LaserJock: Every time the repo is packed (whether an auto-pack or "bzr pack"), obsolete_packs is emptied, then afterwards, any now-unnecessary packs are moved into it.
<Peng> LaserJock: Why?
<LaserJock> Peng: ok, that doesn't make a ton of sense to me but I believe you
<LaserJock> because I don't know how to get rid of it otherwise
<Peng> LaserJock: It'll be automatically emptied later. Why do you need to do it now?
<LaserJock> 1) because i'm trying to figure out repo sizes
<LaserJock> 2) I don't know when it will be emptied
<LaserJock> it was an extra 100+MB sitting in my branch
<Peng> LaserJock: obsolete_packs is used because OSes can't be trusted to immediately write files to the disk. It'd be unfortunate if you had a power failure right after a "bzr pack" and lost all of your data because the file was really sitting in a buffer. This way, you still have the old packs around to recover.

<stanman246> lol
<stanman246> sometimes i work on a project with someone else. Now i'd like to do some kind of version control, he's been looking into bzr already.
<stanman246> It's a webbased project (cakephp) and we're working on the same files every now and then, can this be controlled with bzr?
<jml> yes
<jml> in a variety of ways
<stanman246> ok, will need to go into some tuts i guess
<jml> probably.
<jml> stanman246, have you used a version control tool before?
<stanman246> no
<jml> stanman246, the big difference from just editing files is that rather than just hitting "save", you can group changes together in a single "commit", which generally also has a short description of the change
<stanman246> come across Git, hows that?
<jml> stanman246, roughly speaking it has feature parity with Bazaar. I find it's UI more complex and less helpful.
<stanman246> jml: yes, so i saw
<stanman246> ah
<stanman246> but... bzr is working with .bzr folders locally right?
<jml> stanman246, yes, kind of, but that seems an odd question to ask.
<stanman246> really need to tut first, before asking, sry
<jml> stanman246, are you and your colleague editing PHP files on the web server itself?
<stanman246> not at first
<jml> stanman246, ok.
<jml> that's good :)
<stanman246> we used to use winscp to get the files, edit them and then up them
<stanman246> but with bzr we could edit the files on the server right?
<stanman246> I don't feel really comfy with that thos
<jml> it's not a good way of doing things.
<jml> VCS makes it slightly easier to separate changing the code from doing a release, IMO.
<jml> and changing files onto the webserver in the web area is basically doing a release
<jml> anyway, here's what I'd do to start with:
<jml> make a copy of your code.
<stanman246> local
<stanman246> right
<stanman246> ?
<jml> for now, anywhere.
<jml> just make sure you have a copy in case everything goes horribly wrong
<jml> but also have a copy that you can change into and run 'bzr init' then 'bzr add' and then 'bzr commit'
<jml> this makes a branch that you can play with
<jml> if you put that branch onto the server (either by copying it or running 'bzr push' or something) then you can either check it out ('bzr checkout') or branch it ('bzr branch')

<brmassa> Guys, on C/C++ projects, do you normally track the entire project directory or just the source files?
<AfC> brmassa: "entire"?
<brmassa> AfC: including the "/bin", "/includes" and other possible directories.
<AfC> brmassa: well, if bin/ is _build product_ then no
<AfC> brmassa: ie, no need to version control things that your build creates.
<brmassa> AfC: its useful coz it will track the directories changes (where the project is going to be build), but it also polute the bzr status with tons of files that doesnt need to be versoned
<AfC> brmassa: (I suspect you know that, which is why I'm trying to figure out the nuance of what you're asking)
<brmassa> AfC: yep,.
<lifeless> brmassa: you could 'bzr add --no-recurse bin; bzr ignore bin'
<AfC> brmassa: bzr understands how to ignore things
<AfC> brmassa: but you want to do:
<AfC> $ bzr help ignore
<brmassa> AfC: the makefile/projectfile generally include information that is a little beyond the /src dir, like where to build the project. so it would be nice to track the entire project dir, excluding the content of certain dirs.
<AfC> brmassa: that said, I'm not sure why you'd need to version the directory bin/ if it is a temporary (or final) output of the build. Surely your Makefile (or whatever) knows how to mkdir bin
<brmassa> AfC: my question was more like the common practice than a howto. what people normally do.
<AfC> brmassa: right. So version control Makefile.
<AfC> brmassa: ah. Well, I can't speak for anyone else, but in the GNOME world we don't version control build artifacts.
<brmassa> AfC: hmmm not even the directory structure needed to build a given app?
<AfC> brmassa: there is a *horrible* tendency in the Windows centric side of the Java world to whack .jar files the project depends on into version control
<AfC> (partly because they don't have a proper package management system they can query & reply on, and partly because they're just doing the wrong thing out of sheer bloody mindedness :)
<AfC> brmassa: sure, you can do that, but why not have your Makefile (or whatever) mkdir your temporary & output structure for you?
<lifeless> brmassa: if you need a directory structure, and your toolchain doesn't create it automatically, versioning the structure would be a good idea.
<lifeless> brmassa: what toolchain are you using ?
<AfC> [thereby making it just the sort of thing that can be a) `bzr ignore`d and b) `make {dist,}clean`ed
<AfC> brmassa: other than that, listen to lifeless :)
<Peng> If you have to version e.g. bin, you could still "bzr ignore bin/*".
<AfC> brmassa: [as indeed this isn't the place to talk about comparative merits of different toolchain strategies; bzr can do what you're asking if that's the way you wish to do it]
<brmassa> lifeless: im programming using Qt's qmake. well.... it does create directories if i tell so, but i was wondering to just track the myproject/src dir...
<AfC> Oh, there's a gem: on #cairo, "git has erased all history of that merge"
<lifeless> brmassa: you should track the things that are both: things other people will need to build the software AND things they can't get elsewhere
<brmassa> lifeless: hmmm nicely put
<lifeless> directories that the toolchain can make for you aren't in that set, IMO :)
<AfC> lifeless: that _was_ nicely put
 * AfC takes a quote of that, and then wonders how to properly cite an IRC discussion in a footnote :)
<brmassa> its because i use a specific dir structure on all my projects, like myproject/src, myproject/includes, myproject/bin, myproject/tests, myproject/media, so i was wondering to just version the part of it instead the whole structure...
<brmassa> but for new developers, who wil download the bzr tree, it might help to just see the BIN dir...
<AfC> brmassa: {shrug} they will after they type `make` :)
<brmassa> AfC: yep. maybe u r right.
<AfC> brmassa: in most projects I'm maintainer of, things are structured so that with the exception of a Makefile fragment called .config created by our [custom] top level ./configure,
<AfC> brmassa: *all* the build output runs out into directories under a top level tmp/ that the build creates for itself
<brmassa> AfC: nice. it seems to be the right thing to do. well thank all you guys.
<AfC> brmassa: [with one further exception that there's an entire source tree created during the first step of the build, and so the build mkdir's a tree called generated/ for that]
<AfC> brmassa: [but in this case generated/ is a peer twin of src/ so it rather made sense]
<AfC> [it could have been tmp/generated/ too]

 * spiv looks
<poolie> i think in 2.5 and up 'exitfunc' is not a real method anymore, and
<poolie> probably logging is causing the compatability method aluded to in http://bugs.python.org/issue2356
<poolie> to activate
<poolie> and if i remove that, it breaks
<spiv> poolie: hmm, the stdlib docs do say it might not be set
<poolie> oh?
<spiv> poolie: file:///usr/share/doc/python2.6/html/library/sys.html#sys.exitfunc
<spiv> (And that it's been deprecated since 2.4, but we knew that already I think)
<poolie> mm
<poolie> ok, this is it
<spiv> poolie: so I suppose the correct thing to do is actually "exitfunc = getattr(sys, 'exitfunc', None); if exitfunc is not None: exitfunc()"
<poolie> or to run atexit._run_exitfuncs()
<poolie> or we can just say that there is nothing like that
<poolie> but the getattr is probably a safer change
<spiv> Yeah, we're stuck with either a deprecated interface (sys.exitfunc), or an undocumented one (atexit._run_exitfuncs).
<poolie> yay
<poolie> when in doubt, prefer the smaller diff
<poolie> the good thing about this is that this patch is avoiding loading at least one file (atexit)
<spiv> Although the *implementation* of atexit is actually to install _run_exitfuncs as sys.exitfunc.
<spiv> So in practice it's the same thing.
<poolie> probably not enough to matter, buta  small chance you'd have to wait until the disk head got to it
<spiv> But getattr avoids an import ;)
<poolie> exactly

<Rotaerk_> can bazaar handle having a branch of one repository nested inside a branch of another repo
<Rotaerk_> I'm thinking that I'd like my dependencies handled that way
<Rotaerk_> i.e. one repo per solution.  if the main project in solution A depends on the main project in solution B, I create a branch of solution B's repo inside a folder in the branche of solution A's repo
<Rotaerk_> that way the version of B that A depends on can be updated whenever, and easily
<spiv> Rotaerk_: I don't know precisely what you mean by "solution", and I suspect what you mean by "repository" isn't quite what bzr means, but I think the answer may still be yes.
<spiv> Rotaerk_: if you have branch of one project at foo/, and a branch of another project at e.g. foo/libs/bar, then that's fine by bzr.
<Rotaerk_> hmm okay sounds good, thanks
<Rotaerk_> "solution" and "project" are part of the visual studio code organization model
<spiv> Rotaerk_: bzr won't keep track of which version of libs/bar you happen to have in foo/, but it won't get confused or anything like that.
<Rotaerk_> hmm
<spiv> Rotaerk_: so you can do "bzr pull" or "bzr commit" etc inside foo/libs/bar, and the fact that it's inside foo/ will be irrelevant
<spiv> And similarly you can pull, commit etc in foo/ without disturbing the branch in libs/bar
<Rotaerk_> okay time to try it
<spiv> Yeah, that's the best way to figure this out I think :)
<Rotaerk_> just didn't want to screw up my current repo if bazaar would be confused by it

<drmabuse_> Hello! Anyone an idea how stacked branches differ from others (regular ones)?
<Peng> drmabuse_: Stacked branches don't store all of the revisions locally.
<Peng> drmabuse_: They should function exactly the same as a normal branch, more or less.
<GaryvdM> drmabuse_: A stacked branch does not have all the revsions in it's repository. It has a url to the branch that it is stacked on, and if bzr needs any revisions that are not in it's repository, it gets them from the stacked on branch.

<Peng> You put it very well. :)
<drmabuse_> Ah, thank you!
<GaryvdM> Peng: thanks

<lifeless> jelmer: It would be nice if 'bzr st' behaved as bzr does here.
<lifeless> jelmer: that is, to refresh the index
<mathrick> jelmer: possible, I use bzr-git as more bearable git for working on code with git upstream; what's the least painful setup in this case?
<jelmer> lifeless: sure, but somebody would have to code that up
<jelmer> lifeless: it's nontrivial since we can't really trust the index
<jelmer> lifeless, but we also would like to avoid writing to the index on read operations
<lifeless> jelmer: the index is ~= dirstate, and we write to the dirstate on read operations.
<jelmer> lifeless: but that's just the stat cache though, isn't it?
<jelmer> lifeless, modifying the actual contents of the index seems more dubious to me
<lifeless> jelmer: we don't version or unversion things
<lifeless> jelmer: but I'm not suggesting we do that here either.
<jelmer> lifeless: not versioning/unversioning a particular file, but versioning a particular revision of a fil
<jelmer> "git status" would give different output when run after "bzr status"
<lifeless> jelmer: yes, it would match whats on disk more ;)
<jelmer> lifeless: :-)
<lifeless> jelmer:  you will get complaints either way ;)
<jelmer> lifeless: Yes, and it is the way it is because it doesn't require any effort on my part ;-)
<jelmer> *extra
<mathrick> jelmer: the other way is more useful for the bzr-git user though
<mathrick> I think it's fairly safe to assume that people who use bzr-git are expecting more bzr-like behaviour
<mathrick> jelmer: anyway, how hard will it be to push/send patches upstream if I switch to a bzr tree instead of operating on the git tree directly?
<jelmer> mathrick: it wouldn't be any harder/less hard than using a git repository locally I think
<jelmer> mathrick: The index won't ever be a 1-to-1 match with a bzr working tree
<jelmer> I think the best solution would be to keep a separate sha1-cache independent of the git index
<jelmer> and use that for bzr-git

<Tiriel> Ah! here http://wiki.bazaar.canonical.com/TheBigPicture
<Tiriel> " It is less effective with tree-structured data (e.g. XML), and is most limited in dealing with opaque binary files (e.g. Microsoft Word documents)."
<spiv> Tiriel: well, the builtin merge is designed to work well with text files
<spiv> Tiriel: that's what that's referring to
<spiv> Tiriel: e.g. if you use "bzr merge" and the two branches have both changed the same MS Word document, bzr will only be able to say "there are conflicting changes, here are the different versions of the file, it's up to you to resolve that"

<Tiriel> see, the plan is to do some translation work, so I don't think there will be a lot of merging

<johnf> Tricky questions around merges. I've been asked to compile some stats on the lines of code changed every day for a code base.
<johnf> The metric I've chosen at the moment is just using a diff -c on each commit and pushing that through diffstat
<johnf> this tree is semi complex with lots of feature branches etc.
<johnf> which diverge and then remerge
<johnf> so for standard commits I think this is fine. But what about a commit that is a merge. Am I going to end up double counting changes?
<vila> johnf: a commit including a merge will produce a diff against its left parent, so it will summarize all the diffs in the right parent(s) *and* whatever modifications made to resolve the conflicts
<vila> it really depends on how you want to interpret the resulting stats and whether you drill down into the merges...
<johnf> vila: yeah not the simplest task I've ever been given.
<vila> johnf: if you don't use append_revions_only then it becomes even more.... interesting
<johnf> At the moment I'm tempted to ignore the merge revisions in my stats and assume that conflict changes were small
<vila> one could argue that a merge commit is more work than a regular one though...
<johnf> vila: Yeah agree but I don't see any easy way to avoid the double counting
<vila> may be you shouldn't avoid it
<vila> that's why I said it depends on what you want to interpret, I'm not sure the raw numbers are meaningful, but how they evolve over time may be more meaningful

But since that would be far more invasive to get there, I think None is more precise than False to convey "never"
<vila> s/been/be/ ?

<jam> the fact that IE.executable is defaulted do False, etc
<abentley> vila: I don't see value in having a tri-value where a boolean will do.  There is only one answer to the question "can this be executed"?  And there's no value I can see to a programmer, expecially since None is not clearly distinct from False.
<vila> there is a value is using None to mean: this make no sense
<vila> using False implies True is valid
<abentley> vila: What is the value?  How will this aid my bzrlib programming?  And does the value offset the cost of having to deal with a third potential return value, and the inability to treat the value as a boolean?
<vila> I don't see the value in having a boolean where none is needed either, at least 'None' carries this
<vila> It helps to see None more than to see False as you could then realize that is_executable shouldn't be defined for a dir or a symlink whereas a newcomer may wonder: 'Wait, it's False, when will it be True ?'
<vila> And *that* AIUI is why executability changes were wrongly triggered
<abentley> vila: I am saying boolean values are easier for calling code to deal with.  They can be used in conditionals directly.  They can be serialized using standard machinery.
<abentley> When were executability changes wrongly triggered?  do you mean in the incremental diffs?
<vila> wow, wow, what are you talking about here ? All the code exist to handle this *today* no ?
<vila> isn't it what the bug you're fixing about ?
<abentley> vila: No, I think a lot of the code that exists today treats it as a boolean, and mostly gets away with it.
<abentley> vila: The PreviewTree code treated it as a boolean, and that's the cause of the incremental diff problems.
<vila> so all is left to decide is whether None is better than False because we won't un-implement is_executable for dirs and symlinks
<vila> then why not teach this code that is_executable can be None ?
<abentley> vila: Because a) it's the wrong value b) implementing that decision everywhere would be a lot of code and API changes.
<vila> I can understand that it's *easier* to fix it the way you did, but saying that False == None is a bit... different
<abentley> vila: who's saying False == None?
<vila> you
<vila> executable is never defined for dirs/symlinks, you implement it as False
<abentley> vila: Most assuredly not.  If I tell you that a directory is executable, is that a true statement or a false statement?
<vila> MU :D
<abentley> vila: No, it's not MU.  Even if you argue that the state of a directory's executability is undefined, my statement is false.
<vila> well, if you agree that your statement is false, then all is well :)
<abentley> vila: Indeed, because that means that directories are not executable, and the answer to the question "is this directory executable" is "false".
<abentley> vila: It's not a question of "has the executability of this directory been  toggled to the False state", it's a question of "can this directory be executed".
<abentley> vila: In any case, I hold that a two-value system is less complicated than a three-value system, and therefore in the absence of clear evidence that a three-value system provides a superior API, I believe we should opt for a two-value system.

<alf_> Hi, I am trying to merge a branch containing only one revision and then throw away the changes and replace them with my own. However, when I bzr revert after "bzr merge . -r:tag" the merge is forgotten too.
<alf_> I thought I had to use "--forget-merges" to make bzr bzr forget the pending merge.
<alf_> is this the expected behaviour?
<maxb> alf_: The way it works is as follows:
<maxb> 'bzr revert' reverts tree content and pending merge tips
<maxb> 'bzr revert <paths>' reverts the tree content specified
<maxb> 'bzr revert --forget-merges' reverts only pending merge tips
<alf_> maxb: yes, that makes sense, thanks!

<glyph> Hey, I have a workflow hiccup with bzr that I am wondering if you guys can shed some light on.
<glyph> I frequently encounter diverged branches that I don't really expect
<glyph> this is mainly in my 'personal preferences' repository, which I keep on several machines
<glyph> the sort of pattern is this; I'm on a plane, I make some settings adjustment based on some new tidbit of information (like, a shell helper that I didn't realize was doing a DNS lookup or something like that, that I discover because I'm offline)
<glyph> commit locally
<thumper> poolie: cool
<glyph> then later I make changes to the repository on my desktop, push those changes
<glyph> and then, 30 seconds before I go somewhere, I do a quick 'bzr pull' on my laptop
<glyph> oops!  branches diverged.  but my upstream is kind of crappy, so it takes 45 seconds to actually do the SSH handshake with my server, and I'm leaving for a meeting or something, so I just leave without my changes.
<mkanat> glyph: Ah, you have to do a "bzr merge" in that situation instead.
<glyph> mkanat: Oh, I know *that*.  But 'bzr merge' needs to do the SSH handshake again and deal with RTT again and it's slow.
<glyph> More importantly, I have to do something interactive
<maxb> glyph: Perhaps you would be interested in 'bzr merge --pull' (pull if you can, otherwise merge)
<glyph> maxb: Hmm, maybe that is what I want
<glyph> although
<maxb> Of course, you still need to commit and push
<glyph> what I _really_ want is 'pull if you can, otherwise, put the diverged branch in some helpful location in the same repository, so you can merge from it later'
<maxb> Well, it's not the greatest of UIs, but that kind of already happens (except for the helpful bit)
<glyph> haha
<glyph> maxb: is that bzr's motto?
<glyph> maxb: 'that already works, except for the helpful bit'
<maxb> The not-actually-pulled head will be stored in the local repository and visible in 'bzr heads --dead'
<maxb> you would be able to merge it by revision-id later
<glyph> woah
<glyph> that's pretty awesome
<glyph> so the network I/O actually _does_ happen?
<maxb> sure, it's not just pretending :-)
<glyph> well, I knew _some_ did
<glyph> I didn't realize it actually pulled all of the revs though
<glyph> so, how about this
<glyph> if I make a no-tree branch in my branch and then only ever pull into it
<glyph> then I can just do 'cd upstream; bzr pull'
<glyph> and then 'cd ..; bzr merge --pull upstream'
<glyph> when I have a moment to sit and merge later, but potentially no network I/O
<glyph> hmm, if I do 'bzr get . upstream', it works, but it doesn't appear to use the working directory as a shared repository
<glyph> the branch in question is ~/something, and I don't want ~ to be a shared repository.  'bzr init-repository .' complains that '.bzr' already exists.
<glyph> do I have any option here?
<maxb> erm, possibly
<maxb> let me test something....
<maxb> It's rather cheating quite a lot, but it seems as if 'touch .bzr/repository/shared-storage' convinces bzr to use an existing branch's repository as a shared repository for contained branches
<glyph> maxb: hmm
<glyph> maxb: maybe I don't need to do that
<glyph> now that I'm looking at the output of heads --dead, I can see that it's basically doing what I want
<glyph> yeah
<glyph> okay this is cool
<glyph> maxb: thanks for the info

<spiv> glyph: so the trick is finding the right diverged tip

<glyph> spiv: well, this is why I phrased my requirement that way.
<glyph> spiv: You could have 'bzr pull' specifically remember which tip is the right one, when the branches have diverged, and have other things wipe that memory

<nonix4> if revision x in branch a adds file c, and revision y in branch b adds file d, where d is actually descendant of c... is there a simple way to tell that to bzr after both commits have been made? (both mentioned revisions containing other unrelated changes as well)
<fullermd> I'm not sure what you mean by "descendant".  But the answer will be "no".  Once you've made a revision in the current World Order, it's too late to go back and tell bzr more about it.
<nonix4> except for uncommit?
<fullermd> Well, semantics.  Even uncommit doesn't change a revision, it just pops things off the top of the history and throws them away.
<fullermd> There is occasional discussion about ways to _annotate_ information after the fact (specifically to this case, things like equivalences between separate files).  But it's all speculative and far-future, which doesn't help anything now.
<nonix4> well... how about cherry-picking creation of one file from a distant branch?
<fullermd> You could do that.  Being a cherry-pick, it wouldn't record any of the revision info.  But it would use the same file-id.

<vila> 'bzr resolve --take-other' removes the file-id present in the branch and takes the other one

<crtxc> hi.  Internet where I am is very very unreliable and slow.  Is there a way to resume a branch that has been cut off?  I am trying to branch emacs and it keeps stopping, then I have to start the whole thing over.  I can't find anything via search.
<vila> crtxc: you probably want to pull by batches, so:
<vila> bzr init-repo emacs ; cd emacs ; bzr init trunk ; cd trunk ; bzr pull <trunk url> -r100
<vila> then 'bzr pull -r200' until you get to the tip
<vila> use any increment that your connection can support 1.000 10.000 100.000
<vila> once you get the full history, things should be more reliable as you'll need to download only the new ones
<vila> discussions about allowing more robust branching by automating the above occur from time to time but I don't remember anybody going ahead and implement it

<wilx> Hi.
<wilx> What does 'bzr rmbranch' do exactly?
<wilx> What if I just do 'rm -rf foo' on the branch checkout and directory inside my shared tree?
<wilx> What is the difference?
<jelmer> wilx: rmbranch removes the branch, not the tree or the control directory
<wilx> Hmm, like in the shared repository's metadata?
<jelmer> wilx: in older style bzr branches it basically removes .bzr/branch
<wilx> Or to put it another way around: Can I safely do 'rm -rf foo work-foo' to remove the temporary foo branch from my shared repo?
<wilx> Ah.
<jelmer> wilx: yes

<LarstiQ_> jlf: that depends on what savannah is providing
<LarstiQ_> jlf: but, maybe that is not the problem
<LarstiQ_> jlf: can you verify some other way /emacs/trunk exists and is a bzr branch?
<LarstiQ_> jlf: hitchhiker might be helpful
<jlf> i've used this in the past without incident, but i suspect the firewall is blocking me from this location
<LarstiQ_> aha, then the error is a bit misleading
<jlf> it wouldn't be the first time :)
<LarstiQ_> jlf: other transports are slower, but you could see if http or sftp works (though if ssh works, sftp probably doesn't either)
<LarstiQ_> jlf: myself I'd maybe try tunneling ssh through somewhere else
<jlf> i'm something of a noob -- how can i check and specify the transport method?  iow i can set up a tunnel but i don't know how to tell bzr to go there instead of savannah:22
<LarstiQ_> jlf: if savannah provides the bzr:// protocol you can also try that
<LarstiQ_> jlf: let's see
<LarstiQ_> jlf: either a Host entry in ~/.ssh/config, since bzr calls out to ssh anyway, or
<LarstiQ_> jlf: bzr+ssh://host:port/path
<jlf> LarstiQ_: thanks.  since i don't see an option to specify transport in  bzr up  , how should i specify it?
<LarstiQ_> jlf: that sounds like you're using a checkout
<jlf> i'm an extremely casual user but i have pushed a few changes into the tree successfully this way
<LarstiQ_> jlf: you can use `bzr bind bzr+ssh://host:port` to bind your checkout to something else

<lduros> no local branch or repo
<lduros> ok

<nDuff> lduros: *nod* -- lightweight checkouts are more like the traditional svn way of doing things
<mgz> so, `bzr checkout --lightweight mybranch new-folder`
